awd_titl_txt: PFI-RP: Water System Analytics for Adaptation to Environmental Vulnerabilities
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Partnerships for Innovation – Research Partnerships (PFI-RP) project is the creation of a technical tool and commercial enterprise that promotes and enables adaptation to climate variations in the water sector.  The specific goal for this research is to develop a web-based analysis platform that codifies the analytical methods underpinning advances in decision making under uncertainty to enable broad application of climate vulnerability assessment and adaptation planning. The feasibility research will establish a sustainable industry-university exchange through the development of a joint venture commercial enterprise with industry partners focused on continuous improvement and promotion of the platform. The effort may improve the preparedness of society to weather variations in the water supply industry both in the US and globally. In addition, this effort will educate a female PhD student through academic and entrepreneurship training and mentorship.  The team will recruit a postdoctoral scientist and provide them with mentorship and training according to an Independent Development Plan. 

The proposed project will advance knowledge in the production of climate information that supports vulnerability analysis and adaptation to environmental changes with specific application to decisions in the water supply industry. It will further advance understanding of adaptation planning in the water sector, including insights regarding the opportunities, constraints and impediments to taking action to address vulnerabilities. The goals of the research are to transition processes and technical tools developed from NSF-funded research to commercial use.  A general analysis platform will be developed to create a uniform workflow software package for conducting vulnerability assessments based on decision scaling through collaboration with industry partners. Customer discovery will be conducted to define the value proposition and refine the business strategy. The platform will be piloted in two cities, Miami and Cape Town, both of which are facing threats to their water supply systems. The key technical hurdle is the creation of the platform as a web-based application while maintaining the key functional components of decision scaling. Technical support from industrial partners mitigate the risks associated with this technical hurdle.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This project sought to advance technology development and investigate the market for a hydrologic and climate information platform that would enable water suppliers and other water users to manage their climate-related risk. The research followed from NSF funded basic research for the development of the science underpinning these tools, especially related to climate stress testing through the generation of stochastically generated climate scenarios, coupled with hydrologic modeling and decision analytics. The major accomplishments included deep understanding of the potential market, development of a prototype that targets our identified market opportunity, adoption of AI tools for development of a universal hydrologic modeling capability, and establishment of partnerships.

As a result of this these activities, we launched Tova Earth, Inc., a Delaware C Corp. and have applied for SBIR funding, conducted over 50 pitches with VCs, received $100K funding to date, and been short listed for 2 accelerators, although we have not chosen to pursue those due to unfavorable terms.

The intellectual merit contributions relate to the development of a new AI/ML models for water resources analysis. We developed an AI hydrology model that accounts for the effects of land use change on streamflow and the creation of a new integrated USDA landuse and USGS gauge and watershed data for model training and development. We also developed a decadal scale climate predictio model using bayesian merging of observed trends and GCM simulations. Finally, ML models were developed to predict water use data using a new water demand dataset that we created by directly contacting water utilities.

This project resulted in the launch of a new technology startup, with a woman co-founder, that seeks to assist water managers to reduce and manage their water related risk. This has profound implications for improving water management in the US and abroad in the face of climate change.


Last Modified: 01/09/2025
Modified by: Casey Brown
